thread.title: How mistaken identity cost batsman IPL riches
thread.title_full: How mistaken identity cost batsman IPL riches

title: How mistaken identity cost batsman IPL riches
text:
The 4 worst Jadeja deliveries 1:54 Indian Premier League auction: How mistaken identity cost Harpreet Singh IPL riches  09pm by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS FORGET about Imran Tahir, Ishant Sharma and Brad Haddin, the unluckiest man at the Indian Premier League auction was Harpreet Singh. 
And we must stress that we mean Harpreet Singh and not Harmeet Singh. 
An unfortunately timed case of mistaken identity may have cost him a spot in the IPL. 
With Harpreet sitting atop the run-scoring charts in India’s Syed Mushtaq Ali trophy, (211 runs at 52.75 and a strike rate of 145.51) – a domestic Twenty20 competition – most expected him to win a contract in this year’s IPL. Especially since his reserve price was only $A38,900, which by IPL standards is fairly low. 
But on the day of the auction something went horribly wrong and it had nothing to do with him. A case of mistaken identity cost Harpreet Singh dearly at the IPL auction. Source: Getty Images 
According to multiple media agencies, Harpreet had been arrested for driving his car on to the platform of Andheri railway station in Mumbai, with his name and image splashed all over the internet. That’s some achievement for a man who was nine and a half hours away by car in Indore at the time. 
As it turned out, the man who had driven onto the platform was Harmeet Singh, another first-class cricketer in India who was coincidentally a teammate of Harpreet in India’s Under 19s team at the 2010 World Cup. 
Eventually, the media outlets who had erred corrected their mistake but by that time it was too late for Harpreet, with the Indian Express claiming that the misleading reports had cost Harpreet a bid at the auction. 
“We wanted to buy him, but as news came of Harpreet’s arrest, we decided not to do so since it would give the franchise a bad image. But later, when the auction got over, we came to know it was Harmeet and not Harpreet,” the Express quoted an unnamed franchise official as saying. 
“All is not lost for him. If someone gets injured, we’ll pick Harpreet as first choice.” It was actually Harmeet Singh (front and centre) who drove onto the railway station platform. Source: Getty Images 
Understandably, the 25-year-old was bitterly disappointed with what had transpired. 
“I am clueless right now, as even I don’t know what exactly happened,” he told Cricbuzz. “I did well at the Syed Mushtaq Ali tournament, I wonder if I wasn’t picked because of this confusion or did they never want me at the first place. 
“The news spread like wildfire and everyone had been using my picture and name in connection to Harmeet’s incident. It was all over the media, and all this happened with the IPL auctions unfolding. 
“I was the highest run-getter of the tournament, and now the performances that got me into the players’ pool, have been forgotten. I would still be okay with not being picked for the IPL, but the disrepute that the poor reporting has got me, is something beyond repair,” he said.
